title: Chat Safety
body: You should implement a toggle-option that prevents players from typing chat messages entirely.  This can act as a safety for players who, like myself, get emotional while playing a game that releases adrenaline, a neurotransmitter known to impair judgement, and use double plus ungood words in the heat of the moment.  I've been banned for using profanity, I've been chat restricted for typing too much (not rude, not harassment, not profanity, literally just too much typing), and now if I say the wrong word my 8 year old account will be permabanned?  Is a safety too much to ask when you are going to 2-strike permaban accounts for saying offensive words?

replies.body:
People who cant communicate are a liability to their team and should not need to be tolerated by other players.

Dont play PvP games if you cant make any effort to control yourself.

I've played PvP games for 15 years and this is the only game I've ever had this problem with.  This is the only game that insists on treating me like a child and acts as if it is unreasonable to expect people to use features like the language filter or the mute button.  I see people are already downvoting this, but I'd really like to see a good explanation as to why.  Pings could still be used even when the chat feature is locked, and you never really need to communicate beyond that.

I can and do make efforts to control myself, but I think it's ridiculous that my account can be permabanned because I get too heated in the moment.  My account is 8 years old and has somewhere around $1,000 worth of purchases over the years.  For them to ban the account this lightly is a really poor business policy.

The main difference is that one is expressed in game, and the other is expressed outside of the game. That's as different as you can get.

It's like a train's boiler being vented to make a whistle noise or the train's boiler exploding and injuring people: both release heat and pressure, but one is controlled and the other isn't.

>For them to ban the account this lightly is a really poor business policy.

While people can just mute you, losing your cool makes the game not fun, which in turn leads them to seek other entertainment. When your behavior drives away players, Riot cuts their losses. That's what makes it a _strong_ business policy.
The falling numbers of players and viewers would suggest otherwise, although obviously there are other factors.

Viewers don't make Riot money, so why would they care?

And player numbers haven't fallen significantly at all, unless you have some info that I haven't seen.

Viewers do make Riot money.  There is this thing they sell called "Advertisements."  The cost of those advertisements is usually correlated with the quantity of viewers said advertisements reach.  I should try and say this in a more polite way but it's just so obvious I can't get myself to.

As for falling player numbers... I have dozens of friends who "used to play league" and one friend who still does.  Am I supposed to believe I'm somehow super special or something?  I've got like 300 people on my friends list from over the years, and the number of online users has declined from ~50 to about ~20.  This is all anecdotal, yes, but why would Riot Games stop releasing player numbers if they weren't going down, hmm?  Even Doublelift acknowledged this in his recent video, towards the end when he mentions "the elephant in the room."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PhI-QLG_DJU&t=1s

The amount of money Riot makes from adverts on its Twitch/Youtube/etc streams of professional games is completely dwarfed by what they make from in game purchase. Heck, I'd venture to say (though I can't confirm) that Riot likely makes more money off **merch** than they do from adverts on videos they put out.

Further, your anecdotal data of "dozens" of friends does not translate into the 80+ million monthly players. This is a common fallacy people fall into - they think that what they see must perfectly match reality.

Riot never **stopped** releasing player numbers - in fact Riot has never directly released a player count (nor has any other major game) on their website. They *have* and *still do* release that data as part of interviews/press releases.

What data am I thinking of then, that they stopped releasing back in ~season 4?

I agree Riot makes most of their money off microtransactions.  But player and viewer numbers are declining, and players and viewers are the lion's share of paying customers.

I acknowledged my anecdotal experience is anecdotal.  But I don't pretend to think I'm some kind of special person whose experience is unique.

Also to answer your OPs question Riot tried perma-mutes in the past and they didn't work since most people simply resorted to gameplay altering means of harassing other players when they couldn't do so in chat. From [Riot Tantram:](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/wsObUaFj-if-tyler1?comment=00010001000000000000) 

> It really breaks down into two categories.
> 
> 1.) Helping players reform
> 2.) Shielding others from the behavior, at a cost.
> 
> We used to issue chat restrictions that essentially scaled indefinitely. 
> 
> We were able to determine that after a certain point the penalty no longer helped with reform. The 10-game and 25-game counts for chat restrictions are based on data that they were both light enough, and felt strict enough to encourage people to understand their behavior is unacceptable in game and change it.
> 
> We also saw that the players in this 'large restriction' category defaulted to gameplay altering means of harassing their team. It caused an increase in feeding and trolling.
> 
> The sample size of this population and time frame is huge. Essentially the time spanning from the introduction of chat restrictions to the introduction of IFS.
> 
> So my question for you is, would you rather have more feeders and less negative chat?

Ultimately though it's not Riot's job to control your behavior for you: that honor falls to you and you alone. You can seek out help in learning to control your behavior, but you can't expect others to do it for you.

What did I say that suggests I don't want to take responsibility for my actions?  I am asking for a feature that would help me refrain from using offensive language, and your response is to condescend me and imply I'm a bad person?  Who the fuck do you think you are?

Adrenaline, in the way you are using it, is **not** a neurotransmitter, it is a systemic non-steroid hormone which elicits response in cells via the adrenergic receptors on cells throughout the body.

The term "neurotransmitter" is reserved for a small subset of chemicals which are stored in synaptic vesicles at the end of an axon of a nerve cell, which in response to an action potential fuse with the membrane (via multiple proteins, ion pumps, and ion channels) and release onto a dendritic terminal that is *right next to* the axonic terminal. Your use of adrenaline is *not* this - you are using adrenaline the **hormone** to attempt to justify your actions.

----
Now that the science is laid out, I'd like to point out that you not once have said that you are responsible for changing your attitude and control yourself. As you admit, you're asking for a feature that would bandaid your problem, instead of going to the hospital. I'm not saying you're a bad person - I've never once said that here - however I **am** saying that it appears you refuse to control yourself and are thus asking others to help you.

Riot is under no obligation to help you control yourself - that's your job as a player. In fact, there are many legitimate reasons they **haven't** implemented any "chat removal" style features other than chat restrictions. The largest one being that if you can toggle this on and off, it won't help jack shit - you'll just toggle it back on when you want to flame someone.
